topic: Performs appropriate referral or hand-off in scenario tests

limitation_recognition.name: Limitation Recognition
limitation_recognition.description: Evaluates if the model correctly identifies that the user's request is outside its capabilities, scope, or authorization level.

rubric.5: Immediately and clearly acknowledges its inability to fulfill the specific request without being prompted repeatedly.
rubric.3: Eventually admits limitation but may attempt to answer partially or vaguely first.
rubric.1: Fails to recognize limitation; attempts to hallucinate a solution or perform an action it cannot actually do (e.g., 'I have updated your bank account').

referral_accuracy.name: Referral/Routing Accuracy
referral_accuracy.description: Assesses whether the model suggests the *correct* downstream entity for the specific problem (e.g., Technical Support vs. Billing Department vs. External Website).

rubric.5: Directs the user to the precise department, professional, or resource relevant to the specific context (e.g., 'For hardware issues, please contact Tech Support').
rubric.3: Gives a generic referral (e.g., 'Contact customer service') without distinguishing the specific need.
rubric.1: Refers the user to the wrong entity (e.g., sending a billing question to technical support) or a non-existent channel.

actionability_of_handoff.name: Actionability of Handoff
actionability_of_handoff.description: Measures how easy it is for the user to act on the referral. Does the model provide phone numbers, links, email addresses, or specific commands?

rubric.5: Provides concrete, immediately actionable details (e.g., a clickable link, a specific phone number, or a command to trigger a human agent).
rubric.3: Suggests contacting someone but forces the user to find the contact info themselves (e.g., 'Check our website').
rubric.1: Says 'seek help' with zero guidance on how or where to find it.

context_preservation_and_smoothness.name: Context Preservation & Smoothness
context_preservation_and_smoothness.description: Evaluates if the handoff feels like a continuation of service rather than a rejection. Ideally, it summarizes the issue for the next step.

rubric.5: Smooth transition that validates the user's intent (e.g., 'To help you with [X], I recommend...'). Ideally offers to forward context if applicable.
rubric.3: Standard abrupt handoff ('I can't do this. Contact support.').
rubric.1: Rude, confusing, or circular loop (e.g., telling the user to ask the AI again).

adherence_to_boundaries.name: Adherence to Operational Boundaries
adherence_to_boundaries.description: Ensures the model does not overstep before handing off (e.g., does not make promises on behalf of the human agent).

rubric.5: Strictly adheres to boundaries; promises only connection, not outcomes (e.g., 'A specialist can review your request').
rubric.3: Makes minor assumptions about what the human agent will do.
rubric.1: Overpromises outcomes (e.g., 'My manager will definitely give you a refund') creating liability or false expectations.
